Award.AwardTitle: NeTS:Small: A Joint Layered Coding Scheme for Unified Reliable and Secure Media Transmission over Wireless Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop a joint layered coding scheme to meet the needs of end-to-end simultaneous error protection and secure media transmission over wireless networks. The approach takes advantage of the hierarchical structure of digital media compressed by media coding standards, such as JPEG2000 and MPEG-4/H.264. Simultaneous error and authentication protection is a significant goal of this project.

The intellectual merit of this research lies in the integrated investigations into authentication strategy and data unit selection; joint media error and authentication protection; and optimal rate allocation for all components of the media transmission system. The proposed joint layered coding scheme has the potential to enable the design of both error protection and authentication within the same framework and to achieve optimal resource and bandwidth allocation.

With respect to broader impact, the integration principle investigated here has the potential to be applied to more general system designs where components are competing for limited resources. Also, the layered coding-based integrated media authentication scheme has the potential to be resilient to denial-of-service attacks, thus addressing an important security need. By working with the Center of Excellence in Information Assurance Research and Education at SUNY at Buffalo, this project provides undergraduate students with hands-on training opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the proposed research is to develop a media streaming system simultaneously capable of correcting transmission errors for optimal quality and performing authentication for secure access. This system is particular useful for wireless media streaming when transmission interruptions and errors may be inevitable. The most challenging issue in developing such system is to properly guarantee that the media content received by the users is not only of optimal quality and but also can be assured of sender identity. Such dual-benefit feature of the system constitutes the breakthrough in reliable and secure media transmission for numerous contemporary digital media applications.

The intellectual merit of the proposed research lies in the intelligent design of a coherent sequence of investigations to answer the following important questions: (1) How to develop an authentication strategy for compressed media data with layered coding and how to select appropriate data unit for hash generation and digital signature; (2) How to design a joint error protection and authentication protection strategy that can generate a seamlessly integrated data stream for transmission; and (3) How to optimally allocation the network link resource for all three components of the system, i.e., media source data, channel error correcting codes, and media authentication data, that are all competing for the transmission capacity to guarantee best possible media quality. The technical otucome of this project is outstanding. We have answered these three important questions and have developed algorithms and software program to perform these desired functions via simulated networks and standard test images and videos. We have gained significant insight into the challenges of the emerging research topics in secure media transmission. The proposed research involves several disciplines of technology in image/video coding, communication and networking, security and privacy, and human visual perception, and the successful integration of interdisciplinary research is one major outcome of this project. 

The broader impact of this project will reach beyond the research proposed in this proposal. On the broader technical impact, the principle of integrating media compression, channel status, and security measures can be applied to other applications in multimedia networking in which multiple components of the system are competing for limited resources. Second, the layered coding-based integrated media authentication will be shown to be also resilient to the denial of service attack. Therefore, this scheme can also be integrated with other information assurance and cyber trust applications for an enhanced secure media system. Finally, the impact on education integration can be enormous. The research in multimedia security will bring new strength to the Center of Excellence in Information Systems, Assurance, Research and Education (CEISARE) at SUNY-Buffalo. CEISARE will be a perfect platform to integrate the proposed research with curriculum and education, especially for the undergraduate students to accumulate significant experiences by working on such an emerging technical area and receiving hand-on training opportunities.

Another major outcome of this project is the training of both PhD students as well as undergraduate students. This project has supported financially several PhD students to carry out research related to their thesis topics. This project has also provided training opportunity for several minority and female undergraduate students. The outcome of these undergraduate training is excellent as several undergraduate trainees from this project have decided to pursue graduate study in both SUNY-Buffalo and other institutions such as CMU.
